threads.com:
/lit/ is for the discussion of literature, specifically books (fiction & non-fiction), short stories, poetry, creative writing, etc. If you want to discuss history, religion, or the humanities, go to /his/. If you want to discuss politics, go to /pol/. Philosophical discussion can go on either /lit/ or /his/, but those discussions of philosophy that take place on /lit/ should be based around specific philosophical works to which posters can refer.

Check the wiki, the catalog, and the archive before asking for advice or recommendations, and please refrain from starting new threads for questions that can be answered by a search engine.

/lit/ is a slow board! Please take the time to read what others have written, and try to make thoughtful, well-written posts of your own. Bump replies are not necessary.

>Schopenhauer took as an example (“out of the rich selection of absurdities”) that Hegel believed that mass could become heavier after being magnetized:

>"An example of the existent specification of gravity is furnished by the following phenomenon: when a bar of iron, evenly balanced on its fulcrum, is magnetized, it loses its equilibrium and shows itself to be heavier at one pole than at the other. Here the one part is so affected that without changing its volume it becomes heavier; the matter, without increase in its mass, has thus become specifically heavier."[2]

>—Hegel

>Schopenhauer comments that Hegel not only lacked basic knowledge of physics, but that the “reformer of logic” also did not understand logic: “For, put in categorical form, the Hegelian syllogism reads: ‘Everything that becomes heavier on one side falls to that side; this magnetized bar falls to one side: therefore it has become heavier in that place.’ A worthy analogue to the inference: ‘All geese have two legs, you have two legs, therefore you are a goose.’”[3]

>Two other examples are also discussed. To prevent “the way out of saying that the high doctrines of that wisdom are unattainable by lower intelligences, and that what appears as nonsense to me is bottomless profundity”, Schopenhauer wanted to show that Hegel simply wrote nonsense by using concrete examples. Schopenhauer believed that Hegel could only have gained acceptance as a serious thinker because people do not judge with their own intellect, but instead accept the authority of others, especially of academies.

> Differences in the density of matter are explained by postulating pores. The fact that a bar of iron which is balancing on its fulcrum will lose its equilibrium when it is magnetized, so that the weight of one of its poles will show itself to be greater than that of the other, is an example of the existence of the specification of gravity. One part is so infected here, that it becomes heavier without changing its volume. Consequently the specific gravity of the matter increases, without any augmentation of its mass. Physics attempts to explain density in its own way, by assuming certain propositions, i.e. (1) That given an equal number of material parts of equal size, there will be no difference in weight. From this it follows (2) that it is the measure of the number of parts which determines the weight. It also determines the space, so that (3) two entities of equal weight also fill the same amount of space. Consequently, (4) when two entities of equal weight have different volumes the amount of space they occupy as materials is the same, and their difference is assumed to be the result of their pores. The first three propositions make it necessary to postulate the pores in the fourth. These propositions are not based upon experience however, they are based merely upon the understanding and its proposition of identity. They are therefore formal apriori inventions, as the pores are. Kant has already opposed intensity to the quantitative determination of amount, and posited a constant number of parts with a higher propensity for filling space, instead of more parts in an equal volume. last_replies.com:
NEW FACES IN THE CITY

One must speak of the impostor city.

There is never a design to arrive in this place. One’s destination is always elsewhere. Only as the journey’s end approaches, perhaps too soon or by means of a strange route, may suspicions arise. Then everything requires a doubting gaze.

Yet everything also seems above sensible question. On the occasion that one has set out for a great metropolis, here the very site of anticipation is found. Its monuments spread wondrously across bright skies, and many-colored gardens spread out in the warmth of the day.

But here, one soon observes, nightfall is out of pace. It may be premature, an early darkness unfamiliar in its quality and duration. Throughout these smothering hours there may also be sounds that press strangely upon the fringes of sleep.

The following day one may awake to a different season than the night before had promised. And all the towers of the great metropolis seem hidden behind a mist that draws a pale curtain across the sky. Yet in fact the towers are no longer there.

Through the mist, which hovers thick and stagnant, the city projects the features of its true face. Drab, crumpled buildings appear along streets which twist without pattern like cracks between the pieces of a puzzle. Dark houses bulge; neither stone nor wood, their surface might be of decaying flesh, peeling away at the slightest touch.

Some of these structures are mere facades propped up by a few rotting boards. Others falsify their interiors with crude scenes painted where windows should be. And where a true window appears there is likely to be an arm hanging out of it, a stuffed and dangling appendage with a hand whose fingers are too many or too few.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21284240
Here and there scraps of debris hop about with no wind to guide them. These are the only things that seem to move in these streets, though there is a constant scraping noise that follows one’s steps. If one pauses for a moment to look into a narrow space between buildings, something may be seen dragging itself along the ground, or perhaps it has already laid itself across the street, obstructing the way that leads out of the city. This figure is only that of a dead-eyed dummy, and when someone tries to step over the thing, its mouth suddenly drops open. At the time this is the best the city can do—a sham of menace that has no life and deceives no one.

Only later—when in disgust one has left behind this place of feeble impostures—will the true menace make itself known. And it begins when well-known surroundings inspire, on occasion, moments of doubt. Then places must verify themselves, objects are asked to prove their solidity, a searching hand makes inquiries upon the surface of a window.

Afterward there are intense seizures of suspicion that will not abate. Everything seems to be on the verge of disclosing its unreality and drifting off into shadows. And shadows appear to slide down rooftops, trickle down walls and into the streets like black rain. Your own eyes stare absently in the mirror; your mouth drops open. But it will not close.

Thus, one must speak of the impostor city—and of the perils of bearing it back from a journey and being absorbed as one of its citizens.

the word used in book 1 is κοιμᾶθ', with the last vowel ellided (and the long alpha switched from an eta)
the LSJ provides "lull to sleep" and "lie to sleep" as definitions; in the middle, "lay himself in order to sleep" is a reasonable definition
the word used in book 2 is εὗδον, from εὕδω, and whose semantic range is pretty much just sleep (again check the LSJ)
so basically, while they *can* contradict, Homer uses two different verbs between what Zeus does and what all other gods and men do.

>William Shakespeare (1564 – 1616) was an English playwright, poet and actor. He is widely regarded as the greatest writer in the English language and the world's greatest dramatist. He is often called England's national poet and the "Bard of Avon" (or simply "the Bard"). His extant works, including collaborations, consist of some 39 plays, 154 sonnets, three long narrative poems, and a few other verses, some of uncertain authorship. His plays have been translated into every major living language and are performed more often than those of any other playwright. He remains arguably the most influential writer in the English language, and his works continue to be studied and reinterpreted.
>Shakespeare's influence extends from theater and literatures to present-day movies, Western philosophy, and the English language itself. William Shakespeare is widely regarded as the greatest writer in the history of the English language, and the world's pre-eminent dramatist. He transformed European theatre by expanding expectations about what could be accomplished through innovation in characterization, plot, language and genre. Shakespeare's writings have also impacted many notable novelists and poets over the years, including Herman Melville, Charles Dickens, and Maya Angelou, and continue to influence new authors even today. Shakespeare is the most quoted writer in the history of the English-speaking world after the various writers of the Bible; many of his quotations and neologisms have passed into everyday usage in English and other languages. According to Guinness Book of World Records Shakespeare remains the world’s best-selling playwright, with sales of his plays and poetry believed to have achieved in excess of four billion copies in the almost 400 years since his death. He is also the third most translated author in history.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: 20 most common errors by young authors according to Lovecraft
threads.com:
>Erroneous plurals of nouns, as vallies or echos.
>Barbarous compound nouns, as viewpoint or upkeep.
>Want of correspondence in number between noun and verb where the two are widely separated or the construction involved.
>Ambiguous use of pronouns.
>Erroneous case of pronouns, as whom for who, and vice versa, or phrases like “between you and I,” or “Let we who are loyal, act promptly.”
>Erroneous use of shall and will, and of other auxiliary verbs.
>Use of intransitive for transitive verbs, as “he was graduated from college,” or vice versa, as “he ingratiated with the tyrant.”
>Use of nouns for verbs, as “he motored to Boston,” or “he voiced a protest.”
>Errors in moods and tenses of verbs, as “If I was he, I should do otherwise,” or “He said the earth was round.”
>The split infinitive, as “to calmly glide.”
>The erroneous perfect infinitive, as “Last week I expected to have met you.”
>False verb-forms, as “I pled with him.”
>Use of like for as, as “I strive to write like Pope wrote.”
>Misuse of prepositions, as “The gift was bestowed to an unworthy object,” or “The gold was divided between the five men.”
>The superfluous conjunction, as “I wish for you to do this.”
>Use of words in wrong senses, as “The book greatly intrigued me,” “Leave me take this,” “He was obsessed with the idea,” or “He is a meticulous writer.”
>Erroneous use of non-Anglicised foreign forms, as “a strange phenomena,” or “two stratas of clouds.”
>Use of false or unauthorized words, as burglarize or supremest.
>Errors of taste, including vulgarisms, pompousness, repetition, vagueness, ambiguousness, colloquialism, bathos, bombast, pleonasm, tautology, harshness, mixed metaphor, and every sort of rhetorical awkwardness.
>Errors of spelling and punctuation, and confusion of forms such as that which leads many to place an apostrophe in the possessive pronoun its.

>>21281763
I work 10 hours a day 4 days a week, and hardly write on my days off. And I've still been cranking out about 2k words a day, ~3-4 hours a day NOT counting brainstorming, outlining, and continuity checks. In 10 days I hit 20k words--5 chapters of just introductions to prepare for the actual story. And I just now realized how huge this project is going to end up being. But still I crank out about 2k a day without hardly even trying. If I really tried, and wrote on my weekends too, I'd easily be hitting 20-25k a week.

My point being: if you want it not only will you make time, but you'll not be daunted by the amount of time it may take.

"That Cioran conceives of this [the full acceptance of futility -ed] as so formidable and difficult a task testifies, perhaps, to his own residual, unquenchable good health [here, she both resents and predicts his longevity]. His early books are all great. Hunt for Red October all the way through Without Remorse are all solid technothrillers. He started to go off the rails with Debt of Honor and then went even more off the rails with Executive Orders & Bear and the Dragon. Rainbow Six, released between the last two, was at least enjoyable in a big dumb action movie way though. 9/11 basically broke him (along with a messy divorce apparently) and pretty much everything he wrote after that is even worse. Red Rabbit is a jumbled mess and Teeth of The Tiger is laughably bad but it (almost) loops back around into "so bad it's good" territory. Haven't gotten around to reading any of his later works where he had a co-author or any of his post death novels but I've heard they're improvements.

His biggest problem is he spends dozens of pages on the absolute minutia of military equipment/jargon and it sometimes bogs down the story. He also sometimes injects his boomer neo-con opinions into the stories (this is more of a problem in his later works) so that may bother you. Otherwise I think he's a fine author.

threads.com:
#1 - Facticity and Freedom Edition

The goal of this general is to discuss existentialism and phenomenology, two interconnected traditions in 19th and 20th century continental philosophy. Of special interest is discussion of existentialist phenomenology in particular (roughly the same as existentialism proper), though discussion of non-existentialist phenomenology (such as Husserl) is also welcome. Ignore shitposters and trolls. Be respectful, don't shitfling. Any questions are welcome.

>Facticity and Freedom
This is a common theme in existentialist philosophy. The idea is that there are two parts to the human condition. On the one hand, we are immanent, in the world, as the totality of objective facts. This is also called "facticity." It is the facts that are true about us. We share this with the rest of the world's inhabitants (objects, animals, etc). On the other hand, as human beings there is a second aspect, we are transcendent and go beyond the facts about us, having an inward, subjective experience, we are importantly free. This is also known as "freedom." Many existentialist authors have further things to say about this duality, and how it relates to authenticity, to alienation, to anxiety, and so forth. Thoughts and questions welcome.

threads.sub: The Soul of a Nation Can Be Found in its Literature!
threads.com:
Verily, verily, I say unto you: 'The Soul of a nation can be found in its Literature.'
To this, I may amend: 'Particularly its poesie.'
>What, say you.
Hearken! The incorporeal Soul, whether tripartite or not, drives the body of the nation-state, as it did with petty kingdoms, fiefdoms, empires, and even villages.*
>But how can this be, the reader may now cry, ready to sage this very thread.
Listen, O anons! The Soul is that substance which is not within this world; it arises from the concerted efforts of many great minds of our canonical guardians and deified auteurs. The substance of the world is that of the physical, that of the mundane, that of the machinations of industry and technoscience, as well as the sociocultural exchange of trade and politics; admittedly, the Soul of Literature imbues these very important things with its direction, its articulations, its function. Like many-turned Odysseus, the prophetically epiphanic poetic line of Walt Whitman, "Do I contradict myself? / Very well then I contradict myself, / (I am large, I contain multitudes)," may very well emanate throughout the world as a Soul far greater than the 'Weltseele' of Buonaparte. As with the Cartesian split, the world is composed of the actions of men and the natural, which is supervened by the existence of the stories of the Greats: those who have proven memorable, those who are our light within the encroaching darkness. The Jezebel reading this may throw up their arms in dismay, at this revelation shown to me via Bill the Bard:
>There are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, / Than are dreamt of in your philosophy.
I shall only remark: 'Read, read, read. You shall see the truth of the Soul within Literature.'
For the women of today, their Soul remains in the two mere guineas and in a room of one's own. Everything else about them remains in the body, driven via the locus of the pineal gland of Literacy.
For men, their Soul still remains in the Homeric Hymns ("Ares haughty in spirit, heavy on chariot, golden-helmed") and in those Poundian lines:
>I have brought the great ball of crystal; who can lift it? Can you enter the great acorn of light? But the beauty is not the madness Tho’ my errors and wrecks lie about me.
*I hazard that the songs and oral traditions of our ancient forebears were the Soul within the dales of Arcady (when long ago Lions did roam Europe).

last_replies.name: Anonymouṡ
last_replies.com:
>>21280845
>Is there a literary equivalent of this?

Probably quite a few. A few sort-of examples:

Philip Larkin got fed-up with everyone endlessly repeating This Be The Verse. It's a fairly minor poem (one of his worst, in my opinion) and normies just fixated on it because of the bad language, and ignored all his really good stuff.

William Faulkner became (in)famous for Sanctuary (because of the Rape By Corncob, obviously). It was written just to make money, and is definitely one of his worst books. But by the time of his death his genuine masterpieces had overtaken it, so he wans't as badly off as Tchaikovsky.

D. H. Lawrence was certainly most (in)famous for Lady Chatterley when it finally got published. But that was after he died. Not sure it's his worst book but it's very far from his best.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21283268
Thickness varies with the book, they tweak paper thickness (but not weight) to suit binding size. Either way, it is not really a problem, the tendency of paper to tear is more an issue of short fiber length/density in the paper and the tendency for pages to stick together is more an issue of surface finish and weight of the paper, they use a dense paper with a long fiber which makes it strong and tear resistance and a heavy enough paper with a finish that mostly keeps pages from sticking.

Even their thin paper is thicker than proper bible paper from what I have seen. At most you just need to learn to turn the page of books with thin paper, if the book is not laying flat on a level surface the pages sage (true of all books) and you will have difficulty hooking a single page with your finger on the bottom or side of the book because of how the sagging fans the paper very slightly, so you turn from the top of the page and problem is solved.

Personally I prefer their thinner paper, and thinner paper in general if it is of decent quality, thinner paper is more flexible which greatly decreases the tendency of pages turning on their own when the book is laid open flat or cradled in your hand, no need to keep a thumb in the book.

>" I never shall forget the indulgence with which he treated Hodge, his cat: for whom he himself used to go out and buy oysters, lest the servants having that trouble should take a dislike to the poor creature. threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I'm looking for book suggestions for a specific situation, state of mind change I've been going through. I'm mid-twenties in the work force. The past few years while I was in school I happened to get a job at a funeral home thanks to family connection, it was great pay and the staff was great or I wouldn't have done it. Mainly running errands, picking up paperwork, delivering flowers, going to the grave site pre ceremony to confirm everything was good that sort of thing.
Anyways that put me in the position of constantly encountering funerals, the family and loved ones having to deal with tragic deaths to almost welcomed ones (when they've been painfully sick for a long time). This culminated in working a funeral for a boy my age who was my contemporary who had died of a brain tumor. Seeing his family around his open casket saying their last goodbyes had a switch in me flip some kind of direction.
At same time I was living with my grandfather in his final year of life, watching him slowly decline to the in inevitable end. My uncle also approached death's door and my father had a sudden near-death health scare. All of this occurring alongside the "Big Cough" pandemic that had everyone looking at their health.
What I'm getting at is I'm a young, in-shape healthy guy and I feel like I've spent these past few years too close to the "Realm of Death". I constantly think about death from the perspective of my own decay. Obsessed with thinking about the fact that I could have a heart attack or aneurysm and die on the spot. It's like the real fragility of life entered my worldview and mental space like a freight train and I don't know what to do with it. I'm wondering if any of you have any book suggestions for this feeling, maybe if I could read about a protagonist who deals with the same thing or a similar issue I could help work myself through it. I already read Death of Ivan Ilych on my grandfather's suggestion. He said he read it as a young man and it suddenly hit him in his infirm state that he was Ivan Ilych.

Want this to focus around literature whose major themes and motifs are death and decay. Don't want the jannies dropping this thread because of something /adv/ mental health talk or /x/ wacko shit. Thanks for suggestions you have.

The actual obsession of hispano-american literature is the Independence and its effects: The initial idealism contrasted with the fall of our republican projects, the neverending civil conflicts, the tyranny and the lost dreams of development. This undercurrent of almost nihilisitc disappointment broken from time to time with hopes of resurrection runs throught our entire literary canon, and while the typical, ignorant american can argue "hurr hurr you seething bout whitey" in reality this is very rarely related to modern racial narratives, and when it is, the racial tensions are based on the 20th century and the american domination, not the colony, a period that is left in obscurity by the Independence which is, at the end, our origin myth.
A lot of confusion could be avoided if people understood that the social dynamics between Mexico/Center-America and actual South America are different, and that we don't see ourselves as unified racial groups either. Culturally unified (within a country)? Yes. Racially/ethnically? Lol, no.
